text: so the Threadless case is about new
models of innovation that we're sort of
seeing emerge and in this century
basically focus in on when users become
innovators the intention of the case is
to really highlight how communities work
with firms and how they can innovate
together and the audience that we're
trying to get at is are both you know
our MBA students who are living in this
world of Facebook and MySpace but also
executives who sort of hear about this
and are sometimes scared or are
encountering these types of elements
within their own firms but don't have a
framework to going about and assessing
what is going on in these settings
in some ways the case is pretty
traditional right so it's kind of like
has chapter headings and has had some
writing around it but the main learning
occurs in the videos where the
protagonist and community members are
providing their perspectives for
instance we have a pretty nice
five-minute section on the company
culture now I could have written a lot
about the company culture how they wear
t-shirts and they have dogs running
around the offices and they're playing
pool all the time but they're getting
work done as well that could have been
all in text but to actually see it
visually to sort of experience it as we
go through their offices and their
employees talking back to us and us
observing them in their work environment
was something that captures the culture
in a way that any better text will never
ever capture and I think the students
got a real good sense of or what does it
mean for this kind of company to exist
and for the employees to work here
as part of the experience of Threadless
we told our students to go to the
website and experience you know
participate in a community but then we
wanted to bring it make it fairly real
as well for them and so we set up our
own internal website and we set up our
own t om design contest where they had
to design a t-shirt in their learning
teams focused in around a TM theme that
we would have covered and the idea was
to give them a first-hand experience of
what it takes to design something but
then also to be critiqued by other
people and also to be voted upon
so each learning team had to submit one
design and could be as simple as a stick
figure on a chalk board or something
more elaborate and the idea again was to
to get people to experience a creative
process but also the community process
of critique feedback and ultimately
somebody becoming a winner
